ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to deal with being put in impossible circumstances.
I just learned how frustrating real engineering is.
Quite a few new engineering techniques

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There need to be project suggested at the start, in 487, which are known to be possible and feasible and tick all of the boxes. Letting students come up with their own leads to a wide disparity in the kinds of projects that are being done, the workload, the complexity and marketability. Instructors need to be more understanding and to step in as soon as they see things turning south. This is an important, and necessary course, but it absolutely needs to be handled by people who know what they're doing and who are geared towards students learning, not getting everything right and polished.
The course is very helpful in giving hands-on prototyping and experimenting experience, and would be even better in these aspects in a non-COVID year.

strengths: clearly you learn a bit about what its like in industry and the engineering processes
weakness: it could be a bit more organized and it deserves much more than a half credit, also administrators who have problems with projects should show their faces instead of hiding like cowards, and the stress, anger and mental and physical harm that was caused NOT by my professors but by random higher ups who think what they do doesnt affect the students was ridiculous. if administrators have problems they need to state them at the beginning of the year other wise they need to shut the fuck up

Strengths: you are given a lot of support and resources to build something that provides a lot of educational impact.
Weaknesses: There are still assignments in the course that are filler. I understand that the 3-9 and Gantt chart might be needed as an assignment to keep people updated and on task but they were not useful to my team. The documentation explaining what exactly we have to submit and when is sometimes confusing and contradictory.
This course needs to be a full class credit, it is honestly absurd it is only half a credit based on the amount of class time and hours put in by the students.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: the lab times were awful and the CEID times were crap as well, both needed to be significantly more accessible in order for a successful group project

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No. It's awfully planned and executed.

No.  Dont take if you dont have to.  EHS is a dumb organization.  Those scum bags dont make me safe, they make Yale less fun.  How in Sam Hill can a lawnmower run without a blade.  According to the jerks at Yale EHS it has to for sAfEtY.  I cannot name a single engineer that has THANKED these clowns because every single experience Ive heard about has involved these dumb dumbs watering down the coolness of a reasonable project in the name of sAfEtY.  This slow, inefficient organization is more concerned with shutting stuff down than making stuff work which probably contributes to why Yale engineering is lame and not respected.
if you have to take this course to get the abet degree then take it

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Combination of live lectures and in-person labs.
virtual lecture with in person lab time and team group meeting time
